newsitem.title: GERMANY: Bosnian Serbs must deliver war criminals - Kinkel.
newsitem.headline: Bosnian Serbs must deliver war criminals - Kinkel.

text.p: German Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel said on Sunday Bosnian Serb authorities had to hand over indicted war criminals and said it was in their own interests to fulfil promises made in the Dayton peace treaty last year.

Bosnian Serbs said on Saturday they would not hand over indicted war criminals, despite renewed international pressure to do so and Western threats to deprive them of millions of dollars of reconstruction aid.

"This will not do, Mr Krajisnik!" said Kinkel in a statement, referring to Momcilo Krajisnik, the Serb member of Bosnia's joint presidency. "The international community will not allow the Bosnian Serbs to back out in this way.
"In the Dayton peace treaty all parties agreed to deliver alleged war criminals to The Hague. This pledge must be kept to, to the letter," he said.
Western leaders promised tougher action at a peace review conference in London earlier this week to push Bosnian factions to hand over the dozens of accused still at large.

But they stopped short of authorising the thousands of well-armed NATO peacekeepers in Bosnia to seek out the wanted men and pledged economic punishment instead, a threat the Bosnian Serbs appear not to have taken seriously.
"The Bosnian Serbs must meet their obligations immediately, in their own interests," Kinkel said.
Defence Minister Volker Ruehe echoed Kinkel's comments in remarks due to be broadcast on German radio later on Sunday.
